Award.AwardTitle: MEMS-based Polarization-Sensitive and Doppler Optical Coherence Tomography for In Vivo Diagnosis and Imaging-Guided Surgery

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ECCS-1002209: MEMS-based Polarization-Sensitive and Doppler Optical Coherence Tomography for In Vivo Diagnosis and Imaging-Guided Surgery


The objective this research is to develop a nondestructive optical imaging system equipped with a miniature imaging probe that can be used for arthroscopic diagnosis and intervention of various articular joint diseases and injuries. The approach is to miniaturize the imaging probe by integrating a unique high-fill-factor two-axis MEMS mirror design with a novel packaging technique that requires no wire bonding to MEMS chips.

Intellectual Merits: The proposed optical imaging system is based on Fourier domain optical coherence tomography with polarization-sensitive and Doppler velocity measurement capabilities. Blood flow rate of menisci will be measured in real time. Thereby the proposed system can not only perform in vivo three-dimensional imaging of articular tissues (e.g. articular cartilage, meniscus, etc), but it can also simultaneously achieve high imaging speed, high spatial resolution and high contrast.

Broader Impacts: The success of the proposed miniature imaging probes can be immediately applied to early diagnosis of various cancers including gastrointestinal, bladder and prostate cancers by simply modifying the packaging. The ultra-small probe packaging technique may also enable MEMS mirror-based intravascular imaging for diagnosing and intervening heart diseases. The proposed imaging probes are portable and inexpensive, allowing more people to access medical care and have healthier life. The low-cost probes can be made disposable, which minimizes the risk of disease transmission. Activities are planned to increase engineering enrollment, promote minority students to attend engineering, and outreach to local middle-school and high-school students. The scientific discoveries and technical advancements will be disseminated via online, conference and journal publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Motivation: Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is a powerful optical biopsy imaging technique that offers high resolution and relatively large imaging depth. OCT is well accepted clinically in Ophthalmology and cardiology. Application of OCT to endoscopy is hindered by the stringent size requirements and the need to deal with various sizes and settings for different internal organs when used inside human body. A large effort has been made on developing endoscopic OCT, but no robust endoscopic probes are available.

Objectives of this project: 1) to develop MEMS technology to miniaturize the OCT probe, 2) to develop both forward-view and side-view OCT probes to meet the needs of various uses, 3) to develop Doppler OCT to extend OCT functions, and 4) to develop a common-path OCT for much-simplified system configuration.

Results:

Miniaturization via MEMS technology: Two innovative MEMS mirror designs have been proposed, fabricated and verified. The first design is a hidden-actuator design for achieving high-fill-factor MEMS mirror. The mirror aperture size is 1mm by 1mm and the chip size is 1.55×1.7 mm2, leading to a high fill factor of 32%. This design also enables wire-bonding-free packaging, which can further reduces the probe size. The second design is a 45°-tilted MEMS mirror integrated on a silicon optical bench (SiOB). The Al-coated mirror plate is 0.72×0.72 mm2 and the SiOB substrate is 2.22×1.25 mm2. With this new SiOB design, the endoscopic OCT probe can be significantly reduced in size and its assembly process is much simplified.

New OCT probe designs:

    A side-viewing endoscopic OCT probe based on the double S-shaped bimorph MEMS mirror has been demonstrated, which consists of a MEMS mirror, a flexible PCB, a GRIN lens and an optical fiber. After the assembly process is complete, the entire probe is inserted into a transparent fluorinated ethylene propylene (FEP) tube for protection. The outer diameter of the probe is 2.8 mm. An in vivo imaging experiment using the OCT probe was conducted to detect growing tumor mass. A female athymic mouse was injected with adenocarcinoma cells. The layered structure of the normal tissue was clearly observed. As the imaging position moved over the tumor area, the layered structure was impaired in the OCT images. It is clear that the tumor margin can be detected.

    A forward-viewing endoscopic OCT probe has been developed, which consists of a fiber-GRIN lens-prism module, a MEMS mirror connected to a flexible PCB, a stainless-steel mount base, an encapsulation tube, and a glass window. A MEMS mirror is mounted on a 45° slope after the prism. The light delivered from the fiber and GRIN lens are reflected at the tilted surface of the prism to the MEMS mirror to be scanned in two axes. The assembled MEMS based forward-viewing endoscopic probe has an outer diameter of only 5.0 mm.

    A novel common-path endoscopic OCT probe has also been developed, consisting of a fiber-GRIN lens module, a MEMS mirror connected to a flexible PCB, a stainless-steel mount base and an encapsulation tube. The GRIN lens has an 8°-tilted front end and a flat rear end. The reference surface is designed at the flat rear end of the GRIN lens. This common-path OCT probe uses a side-viewing probe design, which introduces the smallest number of interfaces and minimizes the multiple reflection effect and the artifacts introduced by the interfaces.
